title: Newsom’s Mask Deal Shows Tendency For Big Plans, Few Details
summary:
The announcement surprised many state lawmakers, and California took the unusual step of paying half the cost upfront.
One week later, details of the $1 billion deal with Chinese company BYD are limited — the contract has not been made public, though Newsom's emergency services director said it would be soon.
The mask deal, and how Newsom announced it, illustrates the first-term governor’s tendency to make big pronouncements without all details in place, or before his administration is ready to share them.
Democratic state Assemblyman Richard Bloom, a budget committee member, said details of the BYD deal “are very murky."
Lawmakers want to know how the state is ensuring the quality of the masks Newsom ordered and how they'll be distributed.

title: Abandoned stores, empty homes: why San Francisco's economic boom looks like a crisis | Adrian Daub
summary:
At the beginning of this decade, one beloved block in San Francisco had a taqueria, a flower shop and a bookstore.
But all those closed shops are emblematic of today’s San Francisco, where even in upscale areas, the city’s economic boom can look surprisingly like an economic crisis.
The reasons have a lot to do with the tech economy that’s made San Francisco one of the most expensive cities in the world.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest A recent report found there are roughly 38,000 empty homes in San Francisco – three to five times the city’s number of homeless people.
But walk through parts of San Francisco today, and you get a different sense altogether: not an uncanny effectiveness, but a panicked swirl of homeless capital.

title: Trump administration abruptly moves hundreds of immigrant hearings out of San Francisco
summary:
Northern California immigration attorneys are reeling after learning of a controversial Trump administration decision to move hundreds of immigrant detainees’ court hearings out of San Francisco and to a new courthouse in Van Nuys, a neighborhood in north Los Angeles.
Since Mesa Verde first opened in 2015, its detainees’ cases have been heard before judges in San Francisco’s immigration court.
On 14 January, the Alameda county and San Francisco county public defenders sent a joint letter to the EOIR asking again about the possible move.
He estimated that over the past couple years, possibly 100 of the San Francisco public defender’s clients had been held in detention at Mesa Verde.
San Francisco allocated over $800,000 the same year to expand its public defender’s immigration unit.

summary:
Thousands of pro-life activists converged in front of San Francisco’s City Hall on Saturday for the annual Walk for Life in a festive mood, the day after federal health officials declared illegal a California rule that requires private insurers to provide abortion coverage.
The march, in its 16th year in San Francisco, protests the U.S. Supreme Court’s 1973 Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion nationwide.
Since Trump’s election, nearly 200 pro-life federal judges, including two Supreme Court justices, have been appointed, Pavone noted.
Jessica Munn, chair of San Mateo Pro-Life who has come to the walk in San Francisco every year, handed out literature, as well as plastic models of fetuses at different stages of development while attendees milled around.
Now, she says, there’s momentum going into the 2020 elections, after which activists anticipate one or more Supreme Court seats could become vacant.

title: Winter Storm Brings Hail and... Thunder?
summary:
Today's moderate to heavy rains in SF came with a surprise bout of thunder and lightning.
As this explainer has it, the phenomenon of lightning in a winter storm is called "thundersnow," and it's fairly common in the Midwest and in strong nor'easters.
"Thundersnow requires very strong upward vertical air movement within a winter storm, and is usually associated with highly baroclinic low pressure systems with a source of warmer air (not necessarily above freezing) wrapping into the storm.
The warmer air ingested into the system helps to introduce instability into the cold sector of the storm, which along with the ambient upward vertical motion can produce prolific lightning activity."
So, this frigid storm blowing in from Alaska is running into some warmer air, and thus: lightning and thunder.

A new report by Yelp shows that nearly 500 restaurants closed in San Francisco last year — and some local restaurant owners say they don’t see that trend stopping.
Jardinare, which closed in the spring after 21 years in business, was one of 464 restaurants that closed its doors in 2019.
“It’s not surprising to me at all, I think we’re witnessing the death of restaurants as we know it in San Francisco,” said Ben Bleiman, San Francisco Bar Owner’s Alliance.

title: NOAA: January 2020 was Earth's hottest January on record
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (KGO) -- "In the span of 141 years of climate records, there has never been a warmer January than last month," the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) announced Thursday.ABC7 News Meteorologist Mike Nicco says every decade since the 1960s has been warmer than average.
This surpassed the record set in January 2016 by 0.04 of a degree F (0.02 of a degree C).The four warmest Januaries documented in the climate record have occurred since 2016; the 10 warmest have all occurred since 2002.Breaking the month down by hemispheres, the Northern Hemisphere also had its warmest January on record, at 2.70 degrees F (1.50 degrees C) above average.
The Southern Hemisphere had a departure of 1.40 degrees F (0.78 of a degree C) above average.
It's second-warmest January on record after January 2016.. Record-warm temperatures were seen across parts of Scandinavia, Asia, the Indian Ocean, the central and western Pacific Ocean, the Atlantic Ocean, and Central and South America.
No land or ocean areas had record-cold January temperatures.Polar sea ice coverage remained smaller than normal

title: Bay Area megaprojects: Where 13 major housing developments stand
summary:
As the Bay Area grapples with a massive regional housing shortage, many cities have sought a solution in megaprojects — massive developments that promise to deliver thousands of homes and to help stem the tide of displacement and homelessness.
But this strategy presents an immense challenge: It means that much of the region’s future housing stock is dependent on these extremely challenging and complex large-scale redevelopments.
At least 75,000 units in the Bay Area are part of mega-developments — most of them planned for former industrial or military sites — that are frequently sidetracked for years or even decades due to long approval processes, high infrastructure costs, complicated environmental cleanup issues and financing difficulties.
Here’s a look at some of the region’s largest megaprojects.

The Bay Area earned the lowest score of negative 40; only 24% said it will outperform versus 64% who think it will underperform.
Ken Rosen, chairman of the Fisher Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at UC Berkeley, agreed that the Bay Area will lag the nation this year.
After three years of huge appreciation, prices in the Bay Area were down or flat in 2019, depending on location, he said.
Overall, he expects the median Bay Area home price will be flat to up or down 2%.

title: Here’s where to see the new 2020 ‘Hearts in San Francisco’ sculptures

summary:
It’s not just Tony Bennett crooning about leaving his heart in San Francisco.
There are hearts strewn across that city — giant ones, perched in plazas, gardens and building foyers and tucked away in private collections.
The most famous of them is the 400-pound, painted fiberglass “Tony Bennett’s America’s Greatest City By the Bay” heart in Union Square, which serves as the perfect backdrop for Valentine selfies.
The 2020 Hearts in San Francisco public art project launches next week, the latest iteration of the sculpture series, which features the work of Bay Area artists and has raised some $27 million for research and vital programs at San Francisco General Hospital since the series began in 2004.
Afterward, three of the giant hearts will join the Tony Bennett heart at Union Square from Feb. 14 through Nov. 1.

title: 2020 Brought First San Francisco Rain-Free February Since 1864
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (CBS/AP) — Midnight closed out the first rain-free February in San Francisco since the Civil War, according to the National Weather Service’s Bay Area office.
Neither downtown Sacramento nor downtown San Francisco recorded a drop of rain for the month, according to the NWS.
An hour later another tweet reported light rain starting in North Bay mountains, as part of a system that dumped several inches of snow in the Sierra Nevada.
Sprinkles reported in North Bay Mountains!

This is particularly relevant right now, as highlighted by a Harvard study showing that higher mortality rates from COVID-19 correlate with exposure to air pollution.

title: No measurable rain in February for first time since 1864 in San Francisco
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (KGO) -- It's Valentine's Day and there are no signs of rain in the Bay Area forecast.
"The medium-range models kept trying to grid out a chance of rain for Sunday, but now that's going to happen, even in the North Bay," said Nicco.Nicco's AccuWeather forecast shows no chance of rain for the next seven days.
Go back to Abraham Lincoln days," said Nicco.
"February 1864 was the last time San Francisco measured no rain during the month of February.
"We have a 60% chance of below-average precipitation throughout the remainder of February, so it's not looking good."

title: Heat wave: Bay Area’s temps break records, soar above 80 degrees
summary:

Downtown Santa Rosa registered 80 degrees Tuesday, shattering the previous record of 74 degrees for the same date, set in 1994, according to NWS meteorologist Anna Schneider.
As today's high temperatures trickle in, 5 sites have either tied or broken daily records for today (February 11th).

title: California's homeless census was already troubled. Covid-19 is making it impossible
summary:
With no fixed address and little trust in the government, the homeless population has always been notoriously difficult to track.
While the census falls under the umbrella of the federal Census Bureau in Washington, jurisdictions have the option to form their own committees to work with the regional offices – something the federal bureau has recommended.
Before the coronavirus crisis, the federal Census Bureau planned on counting people experiencing homelessness from 30 March to 1 April.
Photograph: Maria, census regional manager“We have shared the operational plans provided by the US Census Bureau with the homeless service providers and advocates in our community,” the letter reads.

title: It’s not just you. Everybody is reading the news more because of coronavirus.
summary:
We’re collectively reading much more news during the novel coronavirus pandemic than normal, according to new publisher traffic data.
According to Chartbeat, another popular content analytics platform for major publishers, “coronavirus” dominates the top spots in two major categories: the number of people simultaneously reading articles about a topic and the time spent reading those articles.
The amount of time spent actively scrolling, clicking, and reading articles was also up significantly (30 percent) in that time.
While reading more about the virus can contribute to anxiety and even hysteria, much of what people are reading appears to be practical, informative, and action-oriented.
That is, people aren’t just reading articles about what’s happening.

title: Coronavirus: Bay Area air quality is improving as people stay home
authors: Paul Rogers Has Covered A Wide Range Of Issues For The Mercury News Since
summary:
When we look at our measurements, it is below what we were seeing a few weeks ago, for sure,” said Phil Martien, director of assessment, inventory and modeling at the Bay Area Air Quality Management District in San Francisco.
Traffic counts at Bay Area bridges have been roughly 70% lower in recent days than normal, Martien said.
And carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, is off roughly 20% due to the decline in Bay Area driving, Martien said.
“This is not how we want to see air quality go down,” Martien said.
Most months, Bay Area air quality is generally cleaner than in many parts of the world, including in Los Angeles and the Central Valley.

title: Last time SF saw no rain in February was 1864: 'We're on pace to hit that again'
summary:
Last time SF saw no rain in February was 1864: 'We're on pace to hit that again'A sunny day at Dolores Park in San Francisco in February 2020: There's no rain in the forecast through the end of the month.
A sunny day at Dolores Park in San Francisco in February 2020: There's no rain in the forecast through the end of the month.
"The Santa Cruz Mountains have a slight chance of rain, but anything they do get will be very light," said Peterson.
The reason for the lack of rain is a weather system known as a high-pressure ridge that's parked in the eastern Pacific Ocean and steering the storm track away from California.
The rain gauge in San Francisco on average measures 17.94 inches between Oct. 1 and Feb. 19, but this year it has received just 8.83 inches, or 54% of normal.

title: Wells Fargo took a $935 million hit as its own venture capital and private-equity bets sank in the first quarter. Here's a look at how it makes the investments.

Wells Fargo, the fourth-largest US bank by customer assets, said the investments involved were made through Norwest Venture Partners, Norwest Equity Partners, and Wells Fargo Strategic Capital.
Wells Fargo said tanking valuations for its venture capital and private equity investments took a bite out of profits in the first quarter.
Specifically, the firm referred to impairments on investments and activity through its own Wells Fargo Strategic Capital arm and partners Norwest Venture Partners and Norwest Equity Partners.
Norwest Venture Partners and Norwest Equity Partners representatives did not respond to requests for comment.

title: Building a Resilient Planet
summary:
The conventional wisdom holds that climate change is a problem for international organizations, big governments, and global corporations to solve.
Given the monumental scale of the coming climate crisis, anything short of such high-level mobilization seems inconsequential, even futile.
It is true that nothing short of a massive, globally coordinated push can reduce emissions enough to slow down climate change in the decades ahead.
That is why international organizations, national governments, and companies are spending some 95 percent of their climate-related investment on carbon emission reductions.
The fact is that climate change has already done a great deal of damage and that more harmful effects will be impossible to avert altogether.

title: Time Magazine Posts Fake-News Tweet About San Francisco Being On Fire
summary:
The digital-media staffers over at Time Magazine just illustrated the perils of reporting on breaking news via Twitter, without fact-checking, via a mislabeled and mis-captioned video.
Time Magazine, which ironically is owned by SF-based billionaire Marc Benioff as of last fall, published a tweet just after 1 p.m. Tuesday, reposting a video shot at 3 a.m. Monday by San Francisco Firefighters Local 798, showing dashcam video of one of the fronts in the Kincade Fire in Sonoma County.
Clearly the person in charge of the Twitter account, and reposting the video — which was given an added label "San Francisco 10/29/2019" that the original did not have — believed that this SF fire crew was fighting a fire in San Francisco, and not 75 miles north of the city as was the case.
As fires continue to ravage different parts of California, watch as firefighters face massive flames in San Francisco pic.twitter.com/lFjNOQiBqV — TIME (@TIME) October 29, 2019Here is the original video, posted by the firefighters' union.
(Also, not sure why the firefighters' tweet is geotagged "Boise, Idaho," but hey, not everyone gets how the Twitter works.)

Total nonfarm employment grew by 3.5 in San Francisco and San Mateo counties between October 2018 and October 2019, compared with 3 percent in Santa Clara and San Benito counties and 2.2 percent in the East Bay.
San Francisco and San Mateo County added 40,400 jobs in the same period, second only to Los Angeles statewide.

title: Things you do every day are causing trillions of pieces of microplastic to flow into San Francisco Bay
authors: Paul Rogers Has Covered A Wide Range Of Issues For The Mercury News Since
summary:
Every year, 7 trillion tiny pieces of plastic, roughly equal to 1 million pieces each for every man, woman and child in the Bay Area, flow into San Francisco Bay, according to the most comprehensive scientific study yet on the subject.
So San Francisco Bay has a higher concentration of microplastic pollution than many other large bodies of water around the world, the study found.
But the new study found that all those tiny particles are building up in small bay fish, like anchovies.
Most are on pace to met that goal, said Michael Montgomery, executive officer of the San Francisco Bay Regional Water Quality Control Board.

The CHP said the Burlingame woman was driving her Volkswagen under the influence at the time of the crash.
All lanes on northbound U.S. Highway 101 were closed overnight with two left lanes reopened around 5 a.m. All northbound lanes reopened around 7 a.m.

title: First Chance of November Rain Arrives Next Week
summary:
While some meteorologists have given pessimistic outlooks about fire season lasting into December, at least one forecast model has the Bay Area seeing some rain in the middle of next week, on Wednesday morning.
Weather Service model has it arriving from the north and bypassing the Bay Area — what's called an "inside slider" in weather parlance — the European model has it dumping rain across the region all the way to the coast.
As Nicco says, "We are hoping the European model comes through because it will bring a chance of rain in the morning and afternoon hours [next Wedneday."
And he adds that the pattern could set us up for more rain in late November like we had last year.
Meanwhile, it's going to remain an unseasonably warm week in San Francisco and around the Bay.

title: FHLBank San Francisco Releases November 2019 Cost of Funds Index
authors: Federal Home Loan Bank Of San Francisco
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31, 2019 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco (Bank) announced December 31, 2019, that the 11th District Monthly Weighted Average Cost of Funds Index (“COFI”) for November 2019 is 1.035%.
The COFI is computed from the actual interest expense reported for a given month by the Arizona, California, and Nevada savings institutions members of the Bank that satisfy the Bank’s criteria for inclusion in the COFI (“COFI Reporting Members”).
For November 2019, 9 eligible institutions reported COFI data.
Similarly, if a COFI Reporting Member’s Bank membership is terminated, it will no longer be included in the COFI.
For additional information and disclosures about the calculation of the COFI, removal of a COFI Reporting Member, and other matters concerning the COFI, visit the Bank’s website at www.fhlbsf.com.

title: Rain and Hail Possible Around Thanksgiving In the Bay Area
summary:
ABC 7 meteorologist Mike Nicco might have jumped the gun when he predicted possible rain for today as of last week — though there was rain in San Jose last night, as well as some sprinkling across Sonoma and Marin.
But now he's back with a medium-range forecast saying that some real rain will be dumping down starting late Tuesday into Wednesday, with scattered showers continuing into Thanksgiving.
"Thunderstorms are possible with gusty winds, even some small hail and some snow bumping into our mountains," Nicco says.
Chances of rain & showers increasing according to the medium rage forecast model.
Meanwhile, there was reportedly a lightning strike in the Santa Cruz Mountains Tuesday night as a strong storm cell passed through.

title: Bay Area 2019 commercial Dungeness crab season delayed to Nov. 22
summary:
California’s commercial Dungeness crab season will officially start on the coast south of the Mendocino-Sonoma County line on Nov. 22, seven days later than when the season was originally scheduled to begin.
The weeklong delay, one day shorter than an earlier proposal, is the result of a settlement with an environmental group over whale entanglements in commercial Dungeness crab fishing gear.
The state settled the lawsuit in 2018, a process that required the state to end that year’s crab season three months early.
The recreational Dungeness crab season began without delay on Nov. 2.
“Crab season marks the beginning of the holiday party season.

title: Nail-biter SF races may not be decided until next week
summary:
The ultra-tight, undecided races to determine San Francisco’s next district attorney and District Five supervisor will hinge on the roughly 68,000 ballots that the city’s Elections Department still hasn’t tallied.
Although election officials will be working over the weekend, the count won’t be completed until next week, said John Arntz, the city’s elections chief.
Among the uncounted total were 12,500 provisional votes — ballots given to voters whose eligibility must be verified before their votes can be counted.
The Elections Department expects around 10,000 more ballots to arrive by then, but they won’t slow the count much, Arntz said.

title: 35 percent of San Franciscans consider leaving for good, according to city survey
summary:
On Wednesday, the San Francisco Controller’s Office released additional data from the city’s annual resident survey, this time detailing how many people think about leaving SF in the near future.
The city, which released most of its survey data in May, conducted the poll using 2,218 San Franciscans between November 2018 through February 2019.
On the other hand, 42 percent say they’re “not likely at all” to leave the city within the next three years.
The city also notes that, per the U.S. Census estimates from 2013 to 2017, half of the people who left San Francisco move somewhere else in the Bay Area, with Alameda County the most common destination.
According to the U.S. Census, San Francisco’s population continues to rise annually, albeit at a slower rate in recent years.

Google Maps A four-alarm fire broke out in a three-story structure at 456 Castro Street in San Francisco, Calif. Saturday, November 16, 2019.
One person was taken to a burn center with serious injuries and a firefighter was taken to a hospital with minor injuries, according to the San Francisco Fire Department.
The blaze displaced 13 people living in the three-story building.

title: SF district attorney’s race: Suzy Loftus leads Chesa Boudin by a scant 240 votes
summary:
Boudin, an attorney in the public defender’s office, was leading Loftus in first-place votes, 32.9% to 30.9%.
The race, the first open election for San Francisco district attorney in more than a century, intensified last month when sitting District Attorney George Gascón quit early to run, in next year’s election, for the same job in Los Angeles County.
Gascón was widely seen as one of the most progressive district attorneys in the country.
The union representing rank-and-file San Francisco police officers spent more than $600,000 to run attack ads against Boudin.
Meanwhile, a progressive group, Youth and Families Taking Power Supporting Chesa Boudin for SF District Attorney, spent more than $188,000 to support him.

title: Man shot in broad daylight on SF’s Market Street, witnesses say
summary:
A gunman shot a man in broad daylight at the busy corner of Market Street and Golden Gate Avenue Thursday morning, scattering frightened pedestrians.
San Francisco police Officer Joseph Tomlinson said a man sustained non-life-threatening injuries and was taken by ambulance to the hospital.
Manuel Mendoza, 49, who works at Taqueria Can-Cun on Market Street, said he heard two shots, thought it was firecrackers, and ran outside to see what was happening.
The gunman ran south on Market Street toward Seventh Street, Mendoza said.
Officers searched the Powell Street BART Station and nearby streets, including Taylor Street, witnesses said.

title: Coronavirus: COVID-19 may have been spreading in Bay Area since late 2019, according to report
summary:
RELATED STORIES & VIDEOS:Health officials are working to figure out exactly how long COVID-19 has been in the Bay Area.
A new report suggests it could have been long before they started looking for it.Santa Clara County's Chief Executive Dr. Jeff Smith suggests that COVID-19 could have been in the Bay Area and circulating, since late 2019 in December, according to the article in the LA Times That realization is thanks to data collected by the Centers for Disease Control and local health departments.
Dr. Smith also said early detection of the virus lagged because of the severe flu season we were already having in the Bay Area and the overlap in symptoms with coronavirus.
Then there were the guidelines that only travelers recently in Wuhan, China should be screened.
And by that point, it was already spreading within the community.By late February, when doctors finally tested a hospitalized woman who had been sick for weeks, she became the Bay Area's first case of community spread of the virus.

title: Experts Say 49ers’ Super Bowl Loss May Have Saved Lives In San Francisco Bay Area
summary:
Yet in the case of the 49ers’ Super Bowl loss to the Chiefs in early February, it may have been a massive life-saving event.
The story details how doctors in the Bay Area were already working diligently on preparing for the pandemic, which at that point in time had not gained nearly the amount of attention nationally that it would by the end of the month.
It was a heartbreaking loss for the Niners, yet because the virus had already made its way to the Bay Area, it prevented a mass gathering of people from taking place.
The streets of San Francisco were also packed in recent years when the Giants celebrated their three World Series wins.
A Los Angeles Times story this week reported that the coronavirus likely surfaced in the Bay Area as far back as December 2019.

title: San Francisco International Airport Discloses Possible Data Breach
summary:

San Francisco International Airport (SFO) experienced a cyberattack in March 2020 that may have impacted users who accessed SFOConnect.com and SFOConstruction.com, according to a memo sent to all airport commission employees last week.
As such, they may have been able to access some users’ login information for their personal devices during the attack.
Cybercriminals Attack New York AirportThe potential SFO data breach comes after hackers in December 2019 used Sodinokibi ransomware to attack the Albany County Airport Authority.
Furthermore, cybercriminals shared a decryption key with the airport after the ransom was paid, and the airport recovered its encrypted data.

Northern Rural Area Training & Employment Consortium Executive Director Michael Cross issued a release Tuesday regarding Unemployment Insurance claims in the 11 counties the organization works with.
“There were 11,956 new (unemployment) claims for the week ending April 4 in the 11 NoRTEC counties,” Cross said.
There was a jump in unemployment claims in January with 426 filed the week of Jan. 4 and 909 the week of Jan. 11.
Neighboring counties Shasta and Butte had been tied for 33rd of the 58 counties in California at 5.5 percent unemployment in February preliminary numbers.

title: BSL-2 labs should be allowed to handle the novel coronavirus
summary:
advertisementThe advantage is that BSL-2 research and manufacturing capacity is available in abundance compared to BSL-3 and BSL-4 facilities.
advertisementThe way to do that is to reduce limitations on which labs can culture SARS-CoV-2, which means allowing BSL-2 labs to do this.
Three of our portfolio companies are working around the clock on Covid-19 interventions, but all have been stymied by access to BSL-3 labs in recent weeks.
While the more than 200 BSL-3 labs may seem sufficient on paper, the actual number of suites that can be rented by third-party researchers is extremely limited.
As Melanie Ott, a virologist at the Gladstone Institutes in San Francisco, noted in a recent STAT Q&A, research in BSL-3 labs is also more cumbersome.

title: Bank Sites Deluged With Stimulus Status Checks
summary:
Some U.S. banks are experiencing website issues today (April 15) as customers log on to see if their stimulus payment has been deposited.
ThousandEyes, a San Francisco internet and cloud intelligence company, told PYMNTS its tests confirmed the issue isn’t with the web or with increased network demand.
The Charlotte Observer reported online banking services at SunTrust and BB&T Bank were down Wednesday as customers logged on to their checking accounts in search of the federal payment of $1,200, $2,400 or more from the federal government.
Many of those payments, aimed at relieving the economic impacts of the coronavirus, arrived Wednesday via direct deposit to taxpayers.
The report said the stimulus payments that were deposited on Wednesday came on what is typically payday for many workers.

title: AIDSVu Releases Landmark County-Level Data and Interactive Maps on PrEP Use Across the U.S.
summary:
The PrEP data on AIDSVu reveal significant increases in PrEP use year over year from 2012 to 2018.
In conjunction with the launch of AIDSVu's PrEP data and maps, two studies were conducted and published in Annals of Epidemiology, presenting key insights from the county-level data.
For example, in San Bernardino County, Calif. , the rate of PrEP use was 35 PrEP users per 100,000 population compared to 644 PrEP users per 100,000 population in San Francisco County, CA.
For example, in , the rate of PrEP use was 35 PrEP users per 100,000 population compared to 644 PrEP users per 100,000 population in The average rate of PrEP use among all EHE counties and cities was 134 PrEP users per 100,000 population .
Because there is no national registry of all PrEP users, the AIDSVu data represent an underestimate of total PrEP users in a given jurisdiction; the actual number of PrEP users is likely higher.

title: How coronavirus will change the NBA courtside experience
summary:
As the world wrestles with a new normal built around social distancing, working from home and a dormant sports world, one aspect of the NBA experience is especially at risk.
Sitting courtside at an NBA game is unlike any other first row in sports.
One of the most exciting things about the courtside experience is that it’s possible to be in on the conversations between celebrities and players.
But nothing can truly replace the excitement of watching an NBA game courtside, let alone being courtside for a historic playoff run.
“Reggie Miller vs. Spike Lee is so iconic and a definition of the courtside experience and drama of the NBA,” said Wilson.

title: Why independent restaurant owners are fighting 3rd-party delivery platforms like Grubhub and Uber Eats
summary:
Third-party delivery platforms like Grubhub and Doordash claim to be helping restaurants through the pandemic, but restaurant owners say they're doing the opposite.
Third-party delivery platforms like Grubhub and Doordash present themselves as allies of the restaurant industry, claiming to support small businesses by encouraging delivery.
On Monday, a proposed class-action lawsuit was filed against Grubhub, Doordash, Postmates, and Uber Eats for overcharging restaurants to process delivery orders.
For restaurants that had no in-house delivery service before the pandemic, third-party delivery platforms have been a necessary evil.
The owners, brothers Josh and Jeremy George, said that signing up for delivery services enabled them to continue making a profit.

title: More Than 400 San Francisco Restaurants Close in 2019: Report
summary:
More than 400 restaurants in San Francisco shut their doors in 2019, raising concern for many in the city known for its top-notch cuisine.
Jardiniere, one of the most celebrated restaurants in the area is part of the list compiled by Yelp.
“The trend is more restaurants are closing than are opening and that’s historic,” said Chris Tavelli from Pause and Yield Wine Bars.
Restauranteurs said many factors are to blame, like the high cost of operating in San Francisco, high crime rates, dirty streets and long wait times for permits.
“I worry about small businesses in general in San Francisco,” said Oakland resident John Pearson.

title: Flawed approach to IMF programme?
summary:
In the words of the report, “performance under the ongoing IMF programme remains strong, and international rating agencies maintained a stable outlook for Pakistan."
This statement clearly reveals one disturbing, albeit consistent, stance by the SBP notably that the IMF programme conditions including structural benchmarks and, more relevantly, time-bound quantitative actions are not being revisited almost a year into the programme inspite of the pre-Coronavirus slowdown in growth, especially in the large-scale manufacturing sector.
With respect to the real sector the SBP deemed it appropriate to add a special section titled state of competition in Pakistan.
This does need to change and the central bank did well to bring this issue to foreground.
We are sure that the central bank does realise that the changed scenario dominated by the pandemic and its concomitant imperatives dictate obtaining major concessions from the IMF in the ongoing programme as mere tweaking of some of the quantitative conditions alone would not be sufficient.

title: December 2019 astronomy events: Geminid meteor shower, winter solstice
summary:
Keep an eye on the sky in December so you don't miss these exciting astronomy events:Thewill peak on the evening of Dec. 13-14.
AccuWeather describes it as the best meteor shower of the year, saying it can bring up to 120 meteors per hour.
This year, though, a full moon will contest the shower and could wash out the fainter meteors.Thewill begin on Dec. 21, 2019, at 11:19 p.m.
That will usher in the beginning of winter in the Northern Hemisphere and summer for the Southern Hemisphere.On Dec. 26, anwill be visible in the Middle East, southern India and parts of Indonesia.
An annular solar eclipse occurs when the moon is too far away to block the Sun entirely, leaving behind a ring of fire in the sky.

title: Rainstorm Floods Muni and Multiple Corners of San Francisco
summary:
As has happened many times before, heavy rain flooded parts of the Muni Metro system on Saturday, shutting down train service into Saturday evening between Embarcadero and West Portal.
There were small floods all over town on Saturday, with a pretty significant one at Market and Church Street that, obviously, impacted the train tunnels below.
Van Ness Station ultimately reopened after 6 p.m., and some Muni service resumed, though Church Street Station remained closed and trains were not running between there and West Portal.
The National Weather Service reported that San Francisco saw 1.22 inches of rain in 24 hours as of 5 p.m. on Saturday.
As of Sunday morning, Muni reported that the flooding at Church Street Station had been resolved, and normal service had resumed.

title: ‘Continuous’ rain could disrupt 200,000 holiday travelers at SFO, Oakland airport
summary:
A spokeswoman for Oakland International Airport said Tuesday that weather officials had not cautioned them of inclement weather conditions affecting travel, at least not yet.
Flight delays at San Francisco International Airport are always a possibility during rainy weather, SFO spokesman Doug Yakel said.
Holiday travel is expected to peak Friday, when airport officials anticipate roughly 175,000 passengers will depart and arrive.
As of Tuesday afternoon, San Francisco had received 4.16 inches of rain this season, or 64% of normal.
Alejandro Serrano is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer.

title: San Francisco Loses Major Convention, Oracle's OpenWorld, to Las Vegas
summary:
The San Francisco Travel Association (SFTA) confirmed the news in an email to its members Tuesday, saying that Oracle had made the "difficult decision" to relocate next year's OpenWorld conference to Las Vegas based on attendee feedback about how expensive hotel rooms are here.
Instead, in 2020 and the following two years, OpenWorld will be centered at Caesars Forum in Vegas.
The SFTA estimates that the impact of the move will be $64 million in lost revenue to the city.
In a statement given to KRON 4 and others, the company said, "Oracle continues to enjoy a strong relationship with the City of San Francisco and partners such as the San Francisco Giants and the Golden State Warriors.
We look forward to working with our longstanding counterparts in San Francisco on future events."

title: 1 Dead in San Francisco Structure Fire
summary:
San Francisco firefighters are investigating an apartment complex structure fire that left one man dead just days before Christmas.
The two-alarm fire was reported just before 3 p.m. Monday on the 1500 block of Cabrillo Street in San Francisco's Richmond District.
Firefighters said a man was pulled out of the burning building and rushed to St. Mary's Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries.

title: ‘Hang tight’: Periodic rain to continue Thursday, large swells expected
summary:
Periodic rain is expected to continue Thursday across the Bay Area and into the end of the week when the clouds will break — but only for a moment.
“We strongly encourage people to stay away.”Large northwest swells will develop on Thursday and continue through Saturday.
Downtown San Francisco has recorded 23.75 inches of rain since Jan. 1 — surpassing last year’s total of 18.44.
In Oakland, 18.64 inches of rain have fallen since Jan. 1, surpassing 2018’s 15.52 inches.
Alejandro Serrano is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer.

title: The Best New Restaurants In San Francisco, 2019
summary:
It's been a relatively quiet year for restaurant openings in San Francisco — and is it any wonder?
And whether they meant it as a slight or not, this was the first year in a decade that Bon Appetit didn't reserve a spot for San Francisco on its annual top-ten list of best new restaurants in the country.
Three of this year's best new restaurants in SF, in fact, don't even have proper waitstaff — they've gone with counter-ordering models to keep costs down while still serving excellent food.
No doubt, this falls into the category of New San Francisco Places to Drop a Grand on Dinner.
Also, it's truly something special when a restaurant opens in SF in 2019 with nothing on the menu over $12.

title: Storm drenches Bay Area, brings flooding to San Francisco
summary:
A torrential downpour drenched San Francisco on Saturday afternoon, shutting down northbound lanes of Highway 101 for hours.
Cars bound for the Bay Bridge inched along in a 2-mile backup until the freeway reopened at 8:13 p.m.
Wind and rain also toppled a 35-foot tree at Locust and Clay streets that injured two pedestrians, San Francisco fire department spokesman Jonathan Baxter said.
This means flash flooding will be possible with the potential for heavy rain.
“We’ll see more heavier rain through the winter, but no heavy rain in the next seven days,” Anderson said.

summary:

The program contains contemporary holiday songs and also highlights rarely heard holiday music from the 17th and 18th centuries.
"The event features choirs from the CMC Older Adult Choir Program, which provides free community choirs with culturally tailored music for older adults in senior centers throughout San Francisco.
"CMC Coro Solera and Coro Centro Latino de San Francisco Older Adult Choirs, located in the Mission District, will be singing traditional Christmas songs from Mexico, Puerto Rico, and Colombia.
"Coro de Cámara, a CMC adult singing ensemble, will be singing Spanish and Mexican Baroque and Renaissance selections as well as 20th century choral music.

title: Eater Awards 2019: SF Bay Area Restaurant of the Year Finalists
summary:
Today, the process of choosing this year’s stars in the Bay Area restaurant world — the Eater Awards winners for 2019 — continues apace.
There are four finalists in three categories: Restaurant of the Year, Design of the Year, and Pop-Up of the Year.
Besharam, Heena Patel’s Dogpatch restaurant, which has reinvented itself with a renewed focus on bold, soulful Gujarati cooking after relaunching as a solo restaurant earlier this year.
Nari, Pim Techamuanvivit’s elegant Japantown restaurant where chef de cuisine Meghan Clark fuses California ingredients with bright, aromatic Thai flavors.
All of them were key contributors to making 2019 a great year of eating in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: California's Bay Area rocked by back-to-back police shootings over the weekend
summary:
In one incident, police in Santa Rosa shot someone after mistaking their umbrella for a rifleTwo police shootings in a single weekend have rattled the San Francisco Bay Area, including one in which a police officer mistook an umbrella for a rifle.
Witnesses told the San Francisco Chronicle the officers tried to revive the victim before he was taken to the hospital.
Neither Santa Rosa nor San Francisco have released information about the races, genders and ages of the officers or other individuals involved.
A San Francisco police commission spokesperson told the Guardian the department was awaiting the end of the investigation to give an official statement.
According to Santa Rosa’s most recent count, the last time a city police officer shot someone in the city was in 2017, during a home burglary.

title: An 'uninhabitable' shack in San Francisco that's missing a wall just sold for $2 million, and it showcases the real value of land in the Bay Area
summary:
An uninhabitable 640-square-foot shack in San Francisco just sold for $2 million.
However, the property comes with views of the city skyline and a pre-approved demolition permit.
The shack got 2 price cuts: In September, the price of the shack fell from $2.5 million to $2.25 million.
Despite the fact that the shack is unsafe to walk through, the property's nearly $2 million price tag does come with two redeeming factors.
One of those comes in the shape of the views it affords of the city skyline.

title: From auto burglaries to homicides, crime fell in 2019 – The San Francisco Examiner
summary:
That includes a 2 percent decrease in car break-ins and a dip in homicides from 46 in 2018 to 41 in 2019 — the lowest number of killings recorded in San Francisco since 1961, police said.
In 2019, police investigated a number of high-profile robberies involving Chinese seniors in San Francisco.
Earlier this month, Fox News began airing an “American Dystopia” series that depicts San Francisco as a lawless city.
“We have to be very strategic and focused on those people who are doing the most harm to our city,” Scott added.
Law enforcement regularly blames the staggering number of car break-ins in San Francisco on Proposition 47, a 2014 ballot measure that reclassified low-level offenses including certain thefts as misdemeanors.

title: ‘The storm door is open,’ Bay Area weather officials warn
summary:
“The storm door is open and it will remain open,” said Matt Mehle, a National Weather Service meteorologist.
The storm could dump up to 1.5 inches of rain in San Francisco and between 3 and 5 inches in the coastal mountains before leaving the area Sunday.
Heavenly reported 13 inches from Sunday night to Monday morning, Mount Rose reported 24 inches, Alpine Meadows reported 28 inches and Kirkwood reported 46 inches.
San Francisco Chronicle staff writer Greg Thomas contributed to this report.
Alejandro Serrano is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer.

title: Why are California's mayors lining up to endorse Mike Bloomberg?
summary:
But when the billionaire is Mike Bloomberg – and the endorsement is the latest from a string of California mayors he mentored and supported – the vow of support raises some eyebrows.
Bloomberg announced on Thursday that London Breed, San Francisco’s first black female mayor, would serve as his campaign’s chair of African Americans.
It’s not San Francisco endorsing Mayor Bloomberg.
“I haven’t met many Bloomberg supporters in San Francisco,” local lawmaker Matt Haney told the Guardian.
It’s significant that Bloomberg has been able to win the endorsements of black trailblazing mayors like Tubbs and Breed.

title: SantaCon to celebrate 25th anniversary this weekend in San Francisco
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (KGO) -- SantaCon returns to San Francisco on Saturday.People dressed in Santa suits will take part in bar crawls throughout various neighborhoods.But where Santa goes, trouble sometimes follows.Last year during SantaCon, two women were arrested for felony vandalism and battery, after they were caught on video trashing a restaurant on Polk Street.Event organizers are urging people to be respectful.One Santa meeting spot is Union Square, where people are asked to bring a new, unwrapped toy to donate to the San Francisco Fire Department.Rain and wind is forecast throughout the day on Saturday, but SantaCon will happen rain or shine.

title: PG&E protest in downtown San Francisco reroutes Muni buses
summary:
More than 100 people gathered Monday in downtown San Francisco, blocking cars and Muni buses for several hours as they demanded that Pacific Gas and Electric Co. not pay shareholders until it can guarantee electrical power to all of its customers.
San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency officials said the protest near Market and Beale streets forced buses on the 5/5R, 7, 38/38R and 41 lines to be rerouted.
The protesters shut down Beale Street between Mission and Market streets early Monday, and by 12:30 p.m. about 120 had congregated to rally.
A San Francisco police officer at the demonstration said authorities had received a heads-up about the rally planned for noon.
— SFMTA (@sfmta_muni) December 16, 2019Alejandro Serrano and Michael Cabanatuan are San Francisco Chronicle staff writers.

title: SFPD Releases Details, Video From Dec. 7 Officer-Involved Shooting
summary:
The San Francisco Police Department on Tuesday provided details and released bodycam video of a Dec. 7 officer-involved shooting that seriously injured a burglary suspect who attacked and injured officers with a vodka bottle.
At that point, Hampton began attacking the passenger officer with a glass bottle before he exited the vehicle, police said.
When the driver officer exited the car and tried to help, he too was attacked and injured, police said.
Hampton fell to the ground, then rose to his knees and began to move toward the injured driver officer, who also fired and struck Hampton, police said.
The injured driver officer also was treated at the hospital for lacerations on his face and head.

title: San Francisco’s Homeless Population Is Much Bigger Than Thought, City Data Suggests
summary:
Yet data from San Francisco suggest the real picture might be a lot worse.
By this method San Francisco this year reported 8,011 homeless people, a 17 percent increase over 2017, the last time a count was conducted.
[Read more about why homeless populations in cities around the state have surged.]
But San Francisco has another, arguably more comprehensive, way of measuring homelessness, and the results are even more alarming.
Over the course of a full year, the city counted twice as many homeless people — 17,595 people, a 30 percent jump from the previous year.

title: Christmas Eve Shooting in Tenderloin Leaves One Dead, Two Injured
summary:
Police have not released the names of any of the victims, but a 29-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene Tuesday night.
The overall decrease in San Francisco murders this year is continuing to hold, and the city is on pace to see the fewest homicides in nearly sixty years.
After last Thursday night’s Tenderloin shooting, the victim of which has now been identified as 33-year-old San Francisco woman Ronisha Cook, the neighborhood saw another fatal shooting just before 11:30 p.m. Christmas Eve night at Jones and O’Farrell Streets.
Bay City News reports that a fatal Christmas Eve shooting took the life of a 29-year-old man, and left two others with injuries that are not considered life-threatening.
The 29-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene from a bullet wound in the torso.

title: Hundreds Rally in SF, Across Bay Area For Trump Impeachment
summary:
Hundreds of demonstrators gathered Tuesday evening in San Francisco for a rally for impeaching President Trump.
The rally outside the federal building was one of hundreds planned across the U.S.One San Francisco police officer said he believes at least 2,000 people were crowded into the plaza.
"It doesn't matter if you're liberal or conservative, no one should be above the law," said Mick Del Rosario, with United Democratic Club SF.
After the rally in San Francisco, demonstrators marched up Market Street to Sen. Dianne Feinstein’s office.
Rallies also took place in Oakland, San Jose, Palo Alto and Walnut Creek, among other locales around the Bay Area.

title: Bay Area job market surges — but “warning signs” surface
authors: George Avalos Is A Business Reporter For The Bay Area News Group.
summary:
Overall, the Bay Area added 91,500 jobs during the year, 2.3 percent more than in 2018.
In December, the nine-county Bay Area added 2,900 jobs, a monthly report by the state’s Employment Development Department showed.
The Bay Area job market wound up being considerably stronger in 2019 than in 2018.
“There are warning signs for Bay Area employment trends,” said Stephen Levy, director of the Palo Alto-based Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy.
“The Bay Area economic story, particularly in the South Bay, is that companies want to expand, they want to hire people here,” Levy said.

title: San Francisco’s Prettiest New Restaurants For 2019
summary:
San Francisco is home to many beautiful restaurants, thoughtfully designed by cutting-edge design firms and carefully curated by chef-owners with a distinct pride of place.
Of the many new restaurants that opened this year, some trends emerged: Light natural wood, bright white paint, and over-the-top plants are all trademarks of 2019.
But a few restaurants stood out with striking interiors that broke from the pack.
From a huge multi-level food emporium and glittering chocolate factory to lunar lounges and wild wallpaper, here are the most stunning restaurants of the year.
There’s a reason it won best restaurant design of the year.
